Plasma lipoprotein (a) levels are significantly elevated in patients with coronary artery disease as compared to controls.  The contribution of lipoprotein (a) phenotype to the lipoprotein (a) levels in our population, if any, is modest.

Suggest connection between peroxisomal enzyme activity & presence of human LPA gene in murine genome. Effect may be result of changes in oxidative processes in lipid metabolism rather than from direct effect of LPA gene on peroximal gene expression.

Conclude that Lp(a) cholesterol is not an independent risk factor for cardiovascular disease in overweight/obese African American children.

Lp(a) primarily promotes atherosclerotic stenosis rather than venous thrombosis.

In this cohort, no evident association was found between the lipoprotein(a) plasma levels and the incidence of cancer.

Only Lp(a) levels correlated with the extent of coronary artery disease as assessed with coronary angiography in patients treated with lipid lowering therapy.

Genetic variation in the LPA locus, mediated by Lp(a) levels, is associated with aortic-valve calcification across multiple ethnic groups and with incident clinical aortic stenosis.

Elevated serum Lp(a) is an independent predictor of coronary artery disease and myocardial infarction. Furthermore, Lp(a) levels should be a marker of restenosis after percutaneous transluminal coronary angioplasty

Levels of Lp(a) positively correlate with CACs among Chinese Han people who are without diabetes and hypertension, suggesting that Lp(a) may be an important risk factor for the presence of calcified atheromas.
Serum levels of lipoprotein(a) are associated with increased risk of cardiovascular disease despite treatment with niacin and/or simvastatin.

There is lack of association between lipoprotein(a) genetic variants and subsequent cardiovascular events in Chinese Han patients with coronary artery disease after percutaneous coronary intervention.
Lp(a) levels in pregnant women do not differ with respect to the presence or absence of gestational diabetes.

there is a strong inverse association of Lp(a) levels with risk of T2D. However, a genetic variant that elevated Lp(a) levels was not associated with risk of T2D, suggesting that elevated Lp(a) levels are not causally associated with a lower risk of T2D.
Increased plasma lipoprotein(a) level predicts future coronary and cardiovascular events in patients with stable coronary heart disease.
Lp(a) plasma level significantly associates with the risk of cardiovascular events in patients with established coronary artery disease; however, there exists marked heterogeneity across trials
Among white JUPITER participants treated with potent statin therapy, Lp(a) was a significant determinant of residual risk.
data supported an association between serum Lp(a) levels and short-term prognosis in Chinese patients with acute ischemic stroke
Elevated Lp(a) levels are associated with dense fibrin clots. Authors found that the association of LPA 4399Met carriers and clot permeability as well as lysis time differ by ethnicity.
Low lipoprotein(a) concentrations alone seem not to be causally associated with type 2 diabetes, but a causal association for large lipoprotein(a) isoform size cannot be excluded.
Lipoprotein a levels independently predict cardiovascular disease in men and women with familial hypercholesterolemia.

The LPA null allele (rs41272114) is associated with decreased circulating lipoprotein(a) levels and decreased coronary artery disease risk.
Data indicate that lipoprotein (a) Lp(a) is not related to the development of type two diabetes mellitus (T2DM) but may affect clot structure ex vivo without a prolongation of the clot lysis time.

High lipoprotein a levels in angina pectoris patients was significantly associated with binary restenosis in an Asian population.
Lipoprotein(a) might contribute to the development of atherosclerotic renal artery stenosis and detection of elevated levels of this lipoprotein could raise the suspicion of renovascular disease
Niacin lowers elevated Lp(a) level in male subjects with low- but not high-molecular weight apo(a) phenotype.
Assess the role of lipoprotein apheresis in patients with refractory angina and raised Lp(a).
Lipid apheresis treatment of patients with high risk for CVD due to Lp(a) hyperlipoproteinemia was effective, safe, and well tolerated.

Pre-apheresis Lp(a) levels are lower than those before the start of a lipoprotein apheresis treatment but they behave differently among patients during LA treatment.

A Lp(a) plasma level of higher than about 300 mg/L seems to be a threshold for occurring of cardiovascular events. The combination of raised Lp(a) with arterial hypertension was found to be the most important cardiovascular risk factor.

Elevated levels of lipoprotein(a) were not causally associated with increased low-grade inflammation despite a causal association with increased risk of aortic valve stenosis and myocardial infarction.
generated a human apo(a)-transgenic miniature pig that can be used as a model system to study advanced atherosclerosis related to human disease.

Data from a longitudinal, observational study conducted at a teaching hospital in South Korea suggest that elevated serum levels of lipoprotein(a) may serve as independent prognostic factor for development of chronic kidney disease in patients with type 2 diabetes.
The Lp(a) levels were not associated with atherosclerosis in the carotid arteries of statin-treated familial hypercholesterolemia patients.

study provides evidence that ancestry-specific causal risk variant(s) resides in or near LPA and that most of the observed associations outside this narrower region are spurious associations.

Report a significant and independent association between elevated Lp(a) and peripheral arterial disease among Hispanic women and men.

These data demonstrate that serum Lp(a) is elevated in patients with FH caused by PCSK9 gain-of-function mutations to the same level as that in FH caused by LDLR mutations.

Levels of lipoprotein (a) [Lp(a)], a complex between an LDL-like lipid moiety containing one copy of apoB, and apo(a), a plasminogen-derived carbohydrate-rich hydrophilic protein, are primarily genetically rIncreasing evidence suggests that age, sex, and hormonal impact may have a modest modulatory influence on Lp(a) levels. Among clinical conditions, Lp(a) levels are reported to be affected by kidney and liver diseases.

This discovery has sparked intense interest in Lp(a) as a modifiable cause for aortic valve disease. Herein, we will review the mounting epidemiological and genetic findings in support of Lp(a)-mediated valve disease, discuss potential mechanisms underlying this observation, and outline the steps to translate this discovery to a much needed novel preventive and/or therapeutic strategy for aortic valve disease.
High plasma lipoprotein a value is associated with poor prognosis after percutaneous coronary intervention for patients with chronic kidney disease.

tests of association using logistic regression assuming an additive genetic model revealed no significant associations (p<0.05) for any of the five LPA variants previously associated with Lp(a) levels in African Americans

Among patients with acute coronay syndrome, raised Lp(a) levels are associated with an increased atherosclerotic burden and it identifies a subset of patients with features of high risk coronary atherosclerosis.
An association was found between high blood lipoprotein(a) concentrations and a history of stillbirth.
Elevated Lp(a) may identify female patients with increased cardiovascular disease.

name: lipoprotein(a)

reactome.name: Plasma lipoprotein assembly, remodeling, and clearance

summary: The protein encoded by this gene is a serine proteinase that inhibits the activity of tissue-type plasminogen activator I. The encoded protein constitutes a substantial portion of lipoprotein(a) and is proteolytically cleaved, resulting in fragments that attach to atherosclerotic lesions and promote thrombogenesis. Elevated plasma levels of this protein are linked to atherosclerosis. Depending on the individual, the encoded protein contains 2-43 copies of kringle-type domains. The allele represented here contains 15 copies of the kringle-type repeats and corresponds to that found in the reference genome sequence. [provided by RefSeq, Dec 2009].
